user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_monotonic_msec_counter:
```c
uint64_t
MHD_monotonic_msec_counter (void)
{
#if defined(HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME) || defined(HAVE_TIMESPEC_GET)
  struct timespec ts;
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME || HAVE_TIMESPEC_GET */

#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME
  if ( (_MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK != mono_clock_id) &&
       (0 == clock_gettime (mono_clock_id,
                            &ts)) )
    return (uint64_t) (((uint64_t) (ts.tv_sec - mono_clock_start)) * 1000
                       + (uint64_t) (ts.tv_nsec / 1000000));
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME */
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME
  if (_MHD_INVALID_CLOCK_SERV != mono_clock_service)
  {
    mach_timespec_t cur_time;

    if (KERN_SUCCESS == clock_get_time (mono_clock_service,
                                        &cur_time))
      return (uint64_t) (((uint64_t) (cur_time.tv_sec - mono_clock_start))
                         * 1000 + (uint64_t) (cur_time.tv_nsec / 1000000));
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME */
#if defined(_WIN32)
#if _WIN32_WINNT >= 0x0600
  if (1)
    return (uint64_t) (GetTickCount64 () - tick_start);
#else  /* _WIN32_WINNT < 0x0600 */
  if (0 != perf_freq)
  {
    LARGE_INTEGER perf_counter;
    uint64_t num_ticks;

    QueryPerformanceCounter (&perf_counter);   /* never fail on XP and later */
    num_ticks = (uint64_t) (perf_counter.QuadPart - perf_start);
    return ((num_ticks / perf_freq) * 1000)
           + ((num_ticks % perf_freq) / (perf_freq / 1000));
  }
#endif /* _WIN32_WINNT < 0x0600 */
#endif /* _WIN32 */
#ifdef HAVE_GETHRTIME
  if (1)
    return ((uint64_t) (gethrtime () - hrtime_start)) / 1000000;
#endif /* HAVE_GETHRTIME */

  /* Fallbacks, affected by system time change */
#ifdef HAVE_TIMESPEC_GET
  if (TIME_UTC == timespec_get (&ts, TIME_UTC))
    return (uint64_t) (((uint64_t) (ts.tv_sec - gettime_start)) * 1000
                       + (uint64_t) (ts.tv_nsec / 1000000));
#elif defined(HAVE_GETTIMEOFDAY)
  if (1)
  {
    struct timeval tv;
    if (0 == gettimeofday (&tv, NULL))
      return (uint64_t) (((uint64_t) (tv.tv_sec - gettime_start)) * 1000
                         + (uint64_t) (tv.tv_usec / 1000));
  }
#endif /* HAVE_GETTIMEOFDAY */

  /* The last resort fallback with very low resolution */
  return (uint64_t) (time (NULL) - sys_clock_start) * 1000;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_monotonic_msec_counter:
#define HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME 1
...
#define HAVE_TIMESPEC_GET 1
...
#define HAVE_GETTIMEOFDAY 1
...
#define _MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK CLOCK_REALTIME
...
static clockid_t mono_clock_id = _MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK
...
static time_t gettime_start
...
static time_t sys_clock_start
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME
  if ( (_MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK != mono_clock_id) &&
       (0 == clock_gettime (mono_clock_id,
                            &ts)) )
    return (uint64_t) (((uint64_t) (ts.tv_sec - mono_clock_start)) * 1000
                       + (uint64_t) (ts.tv_nsec / 1000000));
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME */
explanation: Fragments not listed do not need investigation for Rule 14.3 because their controlling expressions are not invariant: they depend on function return values or on variables whose values are not known to be constant at compile time. Examples: comparisons that test the return of clock_gettime/clock_get_time/gettimeofday/timespec_get/gethrtime (these are runtime results), the inner checks like if (0 == clock_gettime(...)) and if (KERN_SUCCESS == clock_get_time(...)) and if (0 == gettimeofday(...)) and if (TIME_UTC == timespec_get(...)) are runtime-dependent and therefore not invariant. Preprocessor conditionals (#if/#ifdef) are compile-time feature selection and are outside the scope of MISRA Rule 14.3 (which applies to C controlling expressions). The listed fragments are included because they contain controlling expressions that appear to be invariant (literal 1, a comparison against variables initialized to the same macro value, or checks against symbols of unknown mutability) and therefore should be investigated to determine whether they truly are invariant in the compiled configuration or intentionally used (e.g. for feature selection) and thus acceptable under the rule's exceptions.
